summary.long: Exodus is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: These are the names of the sons of Israel who went to Egypt. Each man and his household went with Jacob:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Issachar, Zebulun, and Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Dan and Naphtali, Gad and Asher.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total number of Jacob’s descendants was seventy people. (Joseph was already in Egypt.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Joseph died, as did all his brothers and that entire generation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the Israelites were fruitful, multiplied quickly, increased in number, and became very numerous. So the land was filled with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a new king arose over Egypt, who did not know Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his people, “Look, the Israelites are more numerous and more powerful than we are.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let’s come up with a wise plan to prevent them from increasing in number. Otherwise, if war breaks out, they would join with our enemies and fight against us. Then they would leave the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Egyptians placed taskmasters over them to oppress them with forced labor. The Israelites built Pithom and Rameses as store cities for Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the more the Egyptians oppressed the Israelites, the more they increased in number, and the more they spread out. The Egyptians were filled with dread because of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Egyptians oppressed the Israelites by forcing them to work very hard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians made the Israelites’ lives bitter with hard work, with brick and mortar, and with all kinds of work in the fields. The Egyptians were merciless in the way they imposed work on the Israelites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt also spoke to the Hebrew midwives. One of them was named Shiphrah and the other Puah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “When you help the Hebrew women give birth, while they are still on the delivery stool, if you see that the baby is a son, you are to kill him, but if you see that it is a daughter, let her live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The midwives, however, feared God, so they did not do what the king of Egypt told them to do, but they let the boys live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt called for the midwives and said to them, “Why did you do this and let the boys live?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The midwives said to Pharaoh, “Because the Hebrew women are not like the Egyptian women. They are vigorous, so they give birth before the midwife comes to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God treated the midwives well. The people also increased in number and became very numerous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Because the midwives feared God, he gave them families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh, however, commanded all his people, “Every son who is born you shall throw into the Nile, but every daughter you shall let live.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a man from the house of Levi went and took a Levite woman as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman became pregnant and bore a son. When she saw that he was a special child, she hid him for three months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she was no longer able to hide him, she got a papyrus basket for him and coated it with tar and pitch. She put the child into it and placed it in the reeds along the bank of the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His sister stood at a distance to see what would happen to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter came down to bathe in the Nile, and her attendants were walking along the bank of the Nile. Pharaoh’s daughter saw the basket among the reeds and sent her servant girl to get it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She opened it and saw the child. It was a boy, and he was crying. She felt sorry for him and said, “This is one of the Hebrew boys.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his sister said to Pharaoh’s daughter, “Should I go and call a wet nurse from the Hebrew women to nurse the child for you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Yes, go.”
So the young woman went and called the child’s mother to come.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh’s daughter said to her, “Take this child and nurse him for me, and I will pay you for doing it.”
So the woman took the child and nursed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the child grew up, she brought him to Pharaoh’s daughter, and he became her son. She named him Moses, with the explanation, “Because I drew him up out of the water.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After some time, when Moses had grown up, he went out to his own people and observed their forced labor. He saw an Egyptian striking a Hebrew, one of his own people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he looked this way and that, and he saw that no one was there, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day when he went out, he came upon two Hebrew men who were fighting. He said to the one in the wrong, “Why were you striking your fellow Hebrew?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The man said, “Who made you a ruler and a judge over us? Are you planning to kill me just as you killed the Egyptian?”
Moses was afraid and thought, “What I have done has definitely become known.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh heard what Moses had done, he sought to kill Moses. Moses, however, fled from Pharaoh’s presence and went to live in the land of Midian. There he sat down by a well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now a priest of Midian had seven daughters. They came and started drawing water. They filled the troughs to water their father’s flock,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but some shepherds came and drove them away. Moses, however, stood up and helped them. He then watered their flock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the daughters came to Reuel, their father, he said, “Why have you returned so early today?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “An Egyptian man rescued us from the shepherds. He even drew water for us and watered the flock.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Reuel said to his daughters, “Where is he? Why have you left the man there? Invite him to have something to eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses agreed to stay with the man. The man gave his daughter Zipporah to Moses as a wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave birth to a son, and Moses named him Gershom, for he said, “I have become an alien living in a foreign land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a long time, the king of Egypt died. The Israelites groaned because of their slavery. They cried out, and their cry for help because of their slavery went up to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God heard their groaning, and he remembered his covenant with Abraham, with Isaac, and with Jacob.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God saw the people of Israel, and God watched over them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses was shepherding the flock of Jethro, his father-in-law, a priest of Midian, and he led the flock to the far side of the wilderness and came to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Angel of the Lord appeared to him in blazing fire from within a bush. Moses saw that the bush was on fire, but the bush was not burning up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said, “I will go over and look at this amazing sight—to find out why the bush is not burning up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Lord saw that Moses had gone over to take a look, God called to him from the middle of the bush and said, “Moses! Moses!”
Moses said, “I am here.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord said, “Do not come any closer. Take your sandals off your feet, for the place where you are standing is holy ground.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text:
He then said, “I am the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob.”
Moses hid his face, because he was afraid to look at God.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: The Lord said, “I have certainly seen the misery of my people in Egypt, and I have heard their cry for help because of their slave drivers. Yes, I am aware of their suffering.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I have come down to deliver them from the hand of the Egyptians and to bring them up out of that land to a good and spacious land, to a land flowing with milk and honey, to the place of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Now indeed, the Israelites’ cry for help has come to me. Yes, I have seen how the Egyptians are oppressing them.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Come now, I will send you to Pharaoh to bring my people, the Israelites, out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses said to God, “Who am I, that I should go to Pharaoh, and that I should bring the Israelites out of Egypt?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So he said, “I will certainly be with you. This will be the sign to you that I have sent you: When you have brought the people out of Egypt, you will serve God on this mountain.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses said to God, “If I go to the Israelites and say to them, ‘The God of your fathers has sent me to you,’ and they ask me, ‘What is his name?’ what should I say to them?”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So God replied to Moses, “I am who I am.” He also said, “You will say this to the Israelites: I am has sent me to you.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: God also told Moses, “Say this to the Israelites: ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers—the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob—has sent me to you. This is my name forever, and this is how I am to be remembered from generation to generation.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “Go, gather the elders of Israel together and tell them: ‘The Lord, the God of your fathers, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Jacob, has appeared to me, saying: I have certainly been paying attention to you and to what they have done to you in Egypt.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I have said that I will bring you up from the misery in Egypt to the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, to a land flowing with milk and honey.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “They will listen to your voice. Then you and the elders of Israel will go to the king of Egypt, and you will say to him, ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has met with us. Now let us go on a three-day journey into the wilderness so that we may sacrifice to the Lord, our God.’
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “But I know that the king of Egypt will not allow you to go unless he is forced to do so by a powerful hand.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: So I will reach out my hand and strike Egypt with all my wonders which I will do in their midst. Afterward he will let you go.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: “I will give this people favor with the Egyptians so that when you go, you will not go out empty-handed.
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: Each woman is to ask her neighbor, as well as any woman staying in her house, for articles of silver, articles of gold, and clothing. You are to put them on your sons and daughters. In this way you will plunder the Egyptians.”
verses.speaker: God

verses.text: But Moses responded, “What if they do not believe me and do not listen to my voice, but instead they say, ‘The Lord has not appeared to you’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the Lord said to him, “What is that in your hand?”
He said, “A staff.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “Throw it on the ground.”
Moses threw it on the ground, and it became a snake, so he ran away from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand and take it by the tail.”
He stretched out his hand and took hold of it, and it became a staff in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “This sign is being given to you so that the Israelites will believe that the Lord, the God of their fathers, the God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob, has appeared to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord also said to him, “Put your hand inside your cloak.” So he put his hand inside his cloak, and when he took it out, his hand was leprous, as white as snow.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said, “Put your hand back inside your cloak.” So he put his hand inside his cloak again, and when he took it out of his cloak, it was restored like the rest of his flesh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said, “If they do not believe you or do not respond to the first sign, they might believe because of the second sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If they do not believe even these two signs or listen to your voice, you are to take some water from the Nile and pour it on the dry land. The water which you take from the Nile will become blood on the dry land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said to the Lord, “Please, Lord, I have never been eloquent, either in the past or more recently or even since you started speaking to your servant, for my mouth and tongue are slow and clumsy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to him, “Who made a mouth for people? Or who makes someone mute or deaf, able to see or blind? Is it not I, the Lord?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go, and I will be with your mouth, and I will teach you what you will speak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “Please, Lord, send someone else.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord’s anger burned against Moses, and the Lord said, “What about Aaron, your brother, the Levite? I know that he can speak well. Look, he is already coming out to meet you. He will be very glad to see you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will speak to him and put the words into his mouth. I will be with your mouth and with his, and I will teach you what you are to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He will speak to the people for you so that it will be as if he were your mouth, and you were God to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will also take this staff in your hand, the one with which you will perform the signs.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses went back to his father-in-law Jethro and said to him, “Let me go and return to my own people, who are in Egypt, and see whether they are still alive.”
Jethro said to Moses, “Go in peace.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses in Midian, “Go, return to Egypt, for everyone who wanted to kill you is dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses took his wife and his sons, placed them on a donkey, and set out to return to the land of Egypt. Moses took the staff of God in his hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “When you go back to Egypt, make sure that you perform in the presence of Pharaoh all the wonders which I have put into your hand. However, I will make his heart hard, and he will not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will then say to Pharaoh, ‘The Lord says: Israel is my son, my firstborn,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and I have said to you, “Let my son go to serve me,” but you have refused to let him go. Watch out. I will kill your son, your firstborn.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At a lodging place along the way, the Lord confronted him and sought to kill him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zipporah took a flint blade, cut off her son’s foreskin, and cast it at his feet. Then she said, “Surely you are a bridegroom of blood to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord left him alone. (At that time she said “bridegroom of blood,” referring to circumcision.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord had said to Aaron, “Go into the wilderness to meet Moses.”
So he went, met Moses at the mountain of God, and kissed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told Aaron all the words that the Lord had sent him to speak and all the signs he had commanded him to perform.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron then went and gathered together every elder of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron spoke all the words which the Lord had spoken to Moses and performed the signs in the sight of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people believed. When they heard that the Lord had paid attention to the Israelites and that he had seen their misery, they bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said, “This is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says. Let my people go so that they may hold a festival for me in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “Who is the Lord that I should listen to his voice and let Israel go? I do not know the Lord, and I certainly will not let Israel go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said, “The God of the Hebrews has met with us. Please let us go on a three-day journey into the wilderness, and let us sacrifice to the Lord, our God, so that he does not strike us with plague or sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the king of Egypt said to them, “Moses and Aaron, why are you taking the people away from their work? Get back to your forced labor!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh also said, “Look, the people of the land are now numerous, and you are stopping them from doing their forced labor.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day Pharaoh commanded the people’s taskmasters and overseers,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Do not give the people straw for making bricks anymore. Let them go and gather their own straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But require them to make the same number of bricks as they made before. Do not reduce it. You see, they are lazy. That is why they are crying out, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to our God.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the work harder for the people so that they do their work and do not pay attention to lying words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people’s taskmasters and overseers went out and told the people, “This is what Pharaoh says: ‘I will not give you straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go, get straw for yourselves wherever you can find it. But there will be no reduction at all in your work load.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people scattered all over the land of Egypt to gather stubble for straw.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The taskmasters kept insisting, “Fulfill your daily quota just as you did when straw was provided!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The overseers, whom Pharaoh’s taskmasters had placed over the Israelites, were beaten. The taskmasters demanded, “Why have you not fulfilled your quota yesterday and today, as you did previously?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Israelite overseers came and cried out to Pharaoh, “Why are you doing this to your servants?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No straw is given to your servants, yet they tell us, ‘Make bricks!’ Look, your servants are being beaten, but the fault is with your own people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “Lazy! You are lazy! That is why you are saying, ‘Let us go and sacrifice to the Lord.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now go! Get to work! Straw will not be provided to you, but you will deliver the same quota of bricks!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelite overseers realized that they were in trouble when Pharaoh said, “You must not reduce anything from your daily number of bricks!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they left Pharaoh, they met Moses and Aaron, who were waiting to meet them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Moses and Aaron, “May the Lord look at you and judge you, because you have made us a stench to Pharaoh and his officials and have put a sword into their hand to kill us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went back to the Lord and said, “Lord, why have you brought trouble on this people? Why did you send me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ever since I came to Pharaoh to speak in your name, he has brought trouble on this people, and you have not rescued your people at all.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Now you will see what I will do to Pharaoh. Because of a mighty hand he will send them away, and because of a mighty hand he will drive them out of his land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God spoke to Moses, telling him, “I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I appeared to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob, as God Almighty, but by my name, the Lord, I was not known to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I also established my covenant with them, to give them the land of Canaan, the land where they were residing as aliens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I certainly have heard the groaning of the Israelites, whom the Egyptians have enslaved, and I have remembered my covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Therefore, tell the Israelites, ‘I am the Lord. I will bring you out from under the forced labor of the Egyptians. I will deliver you from being their slaves. I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with great acts of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will take you as my own people, and I will be your God. You will know that I am the Lord your God, the one who brought you out from under the forced labor of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will bring you to the land which I swore with uplifted hand to give to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob. I will give it to you as a possession. I am the Lord.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses spoke these words to the Israelites, but they did not listen to Moses because of their broken spirit and because of the hard labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Go, tell Pharaoh, king of Egypt, to let the Israelites go from his land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said in the Lord’s presence, “Look, the Israelites have not listened to me. Why would Pharaoh listen to me, since I am a poor speaker?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord again spoke to Moses and Aaron about the Israelites and about Pharaoh, king of Egypt. He commanded them to bring the Israelites out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were the heads of their fathers’ houses:
The sons of Reuben, the firstborn of Israel, were Hanoch and
Pallu, Hezron and Carmi. These were the founders of the clans
of Reuben.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Simeon were Jemuel, Jamin, Ohad, Jachin, Zohar,
and Shaul, the son of a Canaanite woman. These were the
founders of the clans of Simeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the names of the sons of Levi according to their family records: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari. Levi lived 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Gershon were Libni and Shimei. They were founders of clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Kohath were Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel. Kohath lived 133 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Merari were Mahli and Mushi.
These were the clans of the Levites according to their family records.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amram married Jochebed, his father’s sister, and she gave birth
to Aaron and Moses for him. Amram lived 137 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Izhar were Korah, Nepheg, and Zichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sons of Uzziel were Mishael, Elzaphan, and Sithri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Aaron married Elisheba, the daughter of Amminadab and the
sister of Nahshon, and she gave birth to Nadab and Abihu,
Eleazar and Ithamar for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The sons of Korah were Assir, Elkanah, and Abiasaph. These
were the founders of the clans of the Korahites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Eleazar, the son of Aaron, married one of the daughters of Putiel,
and she gave birth to Phinehas for him.
These were the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites that had become clans.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the Aaron and Moses to whom the Lord said, “Bring out the Israelites from the land of Egypt according to their divisions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the same ones who spoke to Pharaoh, the king of Egypt, in order to bring the Israelites out from Egypt. These were that same Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day that the Lord spoke to Moses in the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord said to him, “I am the Lord. Tell Pharaoh, king of Egypt, everything that I tell you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said in the Lord’s presence, “You see, I am a poor speaker. Why would Pharaoh listen to me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Look, I have made you like God to Pharaoh, and Aaron your brother will be your prophet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to speak everything that I command you, and Aaron your brother is to speak to Pharaoh, so that he will let the Israelites go out from his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will make Pharaoh’s heart stubborn. I will multiply my signs and wonders in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh will not listen to you, so I will lay my hand on Egypt and bring my divisions, my people the Israelites, out of the land of Egypt by great acts of judgment.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord when I stretch out my hand over Egypt, and I bring out the Israelites from their midst.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Moses and Aaron did. Just as the Lord commanded them, that is exactly what they did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses was eighty years old, and Aaron eighty-three years old when they spoke to Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and to Aaron,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When Pharaoh says to you, ‘Give us a warning sign,’ then you are to tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff and throw it down in front of Pharaoh, and it will become a snake.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh. They did just as the Lord had commanded. Aaron threw down his staff in front of Pharaoh and his officials, and it became a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then Pharaoh also called for his wise men and sorcerers. Those magicians of Egypt did the same thing by their occult practices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They each threw down their staffs, and those staffs became snakes. However, Aaron’s staff swallowed up their staffs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Pharaoh’s heart was hard, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh’s heart is unyielding. He refuses to let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to Pharaoh in the morning. When he goes out by the water, stand on the bank of the Nile to meet him. Take in your hand the staff that was turned into a snake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You are to tell him: ‘The Lord, the God of the Hebrews, has sent me to you. He says, “Let my people go so that they may serve me in the wilderness.” But look, until now you have not listened.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So this is what the Lord says: “In this way, you will know that I am the Lord.” Look! With the staff that is in my hand, I will strike the water in the Nile, and it will be turned to blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish that are in the Nile will die, and the Nile will stink. The Egyptians will not be able to drink water from the Nile.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Take your staff, and stretch out your hand over the waters of Egypt—over its rivers, its streams, its ponds, and all the reservoirs—and they will become blood. There will be blood in the entire land of Egypt, even in containers made of wood and stone.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron did just as the Lord had commanded. In the sight of Pharaoh and his officials, Aaron lifted up the staff and struck the water that was in the Nile. All the water in the Nile was turned to blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fish that were in the river died, and the river smelled so bad that the Egyptians were not able to drink water from the Nile. There was blood in the entire land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians of Egypt did the same thing by their occult practices. So Pharaoh’s heart was hard, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had told them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh turned and went to his palace. He did not take to heart even this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Egyptians dug around the Nile for water to drink, because they were not able to drink the water from the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven days passed after the Lord had struck the Nile.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, and tell him that this is what the Lord says: Let my people go so that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you refuse to let them go, watch out. I will send a plague of frogs on your entire territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Nile will teem with frogs. They will come up and enter into your palace, into your bedroom, onto your bed, into your servants’ houses, on your people, into your ovens, and into your kneading troughs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will come up on you, your people, and all your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron, ‘Stretch out your hand with your staff over the rivers, streams, and ponds, and bring frogs up onto the land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Aaron stretched out his hand over the waters of Egypt. The frogs came up and covered the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the magicians did the same thing by their occult practices and brought frogs up onto the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Plead with the Lord to take the frogs away from me and my people, and I will let the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to Pharaoh, “I give you the honor of setting the time when I should plead for you, your servants, and your people so that the Lord will rid you and your houses of the frogs. They will remain only in the Nile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh said, “Tomorrow.”
Moses replied, “It will take place just as you have said, so that you may know that there is no one like the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The frogs will leave you and your houses, your servants, and your people. They will remain only in the Nile.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron went out from Pharaoh, and Moses cried out to the Lord about the frogs, which he had brought upon Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did as Moses said: The frogs from the houses, courtyards, and fields died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people piled them up into heaps, and the land stank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that there was relief, he made his heart unyielding and did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Tell Aaron: ‘Stretch out your staff, and strike the dust of the ground, and it will become lice in the entire land of Egypt.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They did so. When Aaron stretched out his hand with his staff and struck the dust of the ground, there were lice on the people and animals. All the dust of the ground became lice in the entire land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians tried to produce lice by their occult practices, but they could not. So there were lice on the people and on the animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians said to Pharaoh, “This is the finger of God.” But Pharaoh’s heart was hard, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning and present yourself to Pharaoh as he is going out to the water. Tell him this is what the Lord says: Let my people go so that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For if you will not let my people go, watch out. I will send swarms of flies on you, your servants, and your people, and into your houses. The houses of the Egyptians will be full of flies. They will even cover the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But on that day, I will deal differently with the land of Goshen, where my people are living. There will not be swarms of flies in Goshen. In this way, you will know that I am the Lord on the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make a distinction between my people and your people. Tomorrow this sign will take place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that is what the Lord did. Thick swarms of flies went into Pharaoh’s palace and his officials’ houses. Throughout Egypt, the land was ruined because of the swarms of flies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “Go, offer sacrifices to your God in the land!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, “It is not right to do that, because the sacrifices which we will offer to the Lord our God would be detestable to the Egyptians. If we offer sacrifices that are detestable to the Egyptians right in front of them, won’t they stone us?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will go on a three-day journey into the wilderness and offer sacrifices to the Lord our God, just as he tells us.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said, “I will let you go to offer sacrifices to the Lord your God in the wilderness, but do not go very far away. Plead for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “All right. As soon as I leave you, I will plead to the Lord so that tomorrow the swarms of flies will depart from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people. Only do not let Pharaoh act deceitfully again by not letting the people go to offer sacrifices to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went out from Pharaoh and pleaded to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did as Moses said, and he removed the swarms of flies from Pharaoh, his servants, and his people. Not a fly remained.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh made his heart unyielding this time also, and he did not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh and say to him, ‘This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go so that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to let them go and keep holding them back,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: watch out, because the hand of the Lord will bring a very severe disease on your livestock which is in the field. It will be on the horses, donkeys, camels, herds, and flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord will make a distinction between the livestock of Israel and the livestock of the Egyptians so that not one of the Israelites’ livestock will die.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord appointed a set time by saying, “Tomorrow the Lord will do this in the land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the next day, that is what the Lord did, and all the livestock of the Egyptians died, but none of the livestock of the Israelites died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh checked and found out that not even one of the livestock of the Israelites had died. But Pharaoh’s heart was unyielding, and he did not let the people go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “Take handfuls of soot from a kiln, and have Moses toss it toward the sky in the sight of Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will become fine dust over the entire land of Egypt, and festering boils will break out on people and animals in the entire land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took soot from a kiln and stood before Pharaoh. Moses tossed it toward the sky, and festering boils broke out on people and animals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The magicians could not stand in front of Moses because of the boils, since the boils were on the magicians and all the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he did not listen to them, just as the Lord had said to Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Get up early in the morning. Present yourself to Pharaoh, and tell him that this is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: Let my people go so that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For at this time I will send all my plagues against you yourself, your servants, and your people, so that you will know that there is no one like me in all the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For by now I could have stretched out my hand and struck you and your people with a plague so that you would have been wiped off the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, for this very reason, I caused you to stand: so that I could show you my power, and that my name would be made known over the entire earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You still are acting arrogantly against my people by not letting them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Watch out. At this time tomorrow I will rain down a very severe hailstorm, unlike any other in Egypt from the day it was founded until now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now give orders to bring your livestock and everything of yours that is in the open field into shelters. Every person and animal out in the open that is not brought inside will die when the hail falls down on them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Those among Pharaoh’s officials who feared the word of the Lord made their servants and livestock take refuge inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But those who did not take the word of the Lord to heart left their servants and livestock in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward the sky, and let there be hail in the entire land of Egypt: on the people, on the animals, and on every plant in the field throughout the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his staff toward the sky, and the Lord sent thunder and hail. Lightning also flashed down to the ground. The Lord rained down hail upon the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hail, with lightning flashing through it, was very severe. Nothing like it had happened in the entire land of Egypt since it became a nation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Throughout the entire land, the hail struck everything that was in the field, both people and animals. The hail also struck every plant in the field and shattered every tree in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But in the land of Goshen, where the Israelites were, there was no hail.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron. He said to them, “I have sinned this time. The Lord is the one who is in the right, and I and my people are in the wrong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Plead to the Lord, for there has been enough of God’s thunder and hail. I will let you go, and you do not have to stay here any longer.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to him, “When I have gone out of the city, I will spread out my hands to the Lord. The thunder will stop, and there will no longer be any hail, so that you may know that the earth belongs to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But as for you and your officials, I know that you still do not fear the Lord God.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The flax and the barley were destroyed, because the barley was ripe and the flax was in bloom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the wheat and the spelt were not destroyed, because they ripen later.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went out from Pharaoh and from the city. He spread out his hands to the Lord. The thunder and hail stopped, and the rain no longer poured down on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Pharaoh saw that the rain, hail, and thunder had stopped, he sinned again. He and his officials made their hearts unyielding.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s heart was hard, and he did not let the Israelites go, just as the Lord had said through Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go to Pharaoh, for I have made his heart unyielding, and his officials’ hearts too, so that I may perform these signs of mine in their midst,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and so that you may tell your children and your grandchildren how harshly I dealt with Egypt and about my signs which I did among them. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron went to Pharaoh and said to him, “This is what the Lord, the God of the Hebrews, says: How long will you refuse to humble yourself before me? Let my people go so that they may serve me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you refuse to let my people go, watch out, because tomorrow I will bring locusts into your territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will cover the surface of the ground so that no one will be able to see the ground. The locusts will eat what little you have left after the hail. They will also eat every tree that you have growing in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your houses, your officials’ houses, and every Egyptian’s house will be filled with them, something neither your fathers nor your fathers’ fathers have seen, from the day that they settled in this land up to this day.” Then he turned and went out from Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s officials said to him, “How long will this man be a snare to us? Let the men go so that they may serve the Lord, their God. Do you not yet realize that Egypt is ruined?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron were brought back to Pharaoh, and he said to them, “Go, serve the Lord your God. But who exactly would be going?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “We will go with our young and old, with our sons and daughters. We will go with our flocks and herds, for we are celebrating a festival to the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said to them, “May the Lord be with you if I would ever let you and your families go! I see you are determined to do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No! The men may go and serve the Lord, for that is what you have been asking for!” Then they were driven out from Pharaoh’s presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the land of Egypt so that locusts come up over the land and eat every plant in the land, everything left by the hail.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his staff over the land of Egypt, and the Lord made an east wind blow over the land all that day and all through the night. When morning came, the east wind had brought the locusts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The locusts came up over the entire land of Egypt and settled down in the entire territory of Egypt. There had never been such a large number of locusts before, and there would never be again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They covered the surface of the ground so completely that the land was dark. They ate every plant of the land and all the fruit of the trees—everything left after the hail. Nothing green was left on the trees or on the plants in the field throughout the entire land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh quickly summoned Moses and Aaron and said, “I have sinned against the Lord your God and against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now please forgive my sin once more, and plead to the Lord your God so that he may also remove this death from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went out from Pharaoh and pleaded with the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord changed the wind to a very strong west wind. That wind lifted up the locusts and drove them into the Red Sea. Not one locust remained in the entire territory of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart hard, and he did not let the Israelites go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand toward the sky, so that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, darkness that can be felt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses stretched out his hand toward the sky, and there was a thick darkness in the entire land of Egypt for three days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one could see anyone else, and for three days none of them moved from where they were. Yet all the Israelites had light where they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh called to Moses and said, “Go, serve the Lord. Even your families may also go with you. But you must leave your flocks and herds behind.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Moses said, “You must also let us take sacrifices with us and burnt offerings to present to the Lord our God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our livestock must also go with us. Not a hoof is to be left behind, for we must take some of them to serve the Lord our God. We will not know, however, what we will need to serve the Lord until we get there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Lord hardened Pharaoh’s heart, and he would not let them go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh said to Moses, “Get out of my sight! Make sure you do not see my face again, for on the day you see my face, you will die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Just as you have spoken: I will never see your face again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “I will bring one more plague on Pharaoh and on Egypt. After that, he will let you go from here. When he lets you go, he will certainly drive you completely out of here.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now tell the people that both the men and the women are to ask their neighbors for articles of silver and gold.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The Lord had given the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians. Even the man Moses was highly regarded in the land of Egypt in the sight of Pharaoh’s officials and the people.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses said, “This is what the Lord says. About midnight I will go throughout Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and every firstborn in the land of Egypt will die, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sits on his throne, to the firstborn of the female slave who is behind the hand mill, even all the firstborn of the livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There will be a loud outcry in the entire land of Egypt, unlike anything that happened before or anything that will take place again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But among all the Israelites, not a dog will bark at a person or animal, so that you may know that the Lord makes a distinction between Egypt and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All these officials of yours will come and bow down to me, saying, ‘Get out, you and all the people who follow you!’ After that, I will leave.” Then Moses, hot with anger, went out from Pharaoh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Pharaoh will not listen to you so that my wonders may be multiplied in the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses and Aaron performed all these wonders before Pharaoh, but the Lord made Pharaoh’s heart hard, and he did not let the Israelites go out of his land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord told Moses and Aaron this in the land of Egypt:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This month is to be the beginning of your calendar. It is to be the first month of the year for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tell the entire Israelite community that on the tenth day of this month, they are to take a lamb or a young goat for themselves, according to their fathers’ households, one lamb per household.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the household is too small for a whole lamb, then that person and his neighbor next door to him must select one, based on the number of people. Determine what size lamb is needed according to how much each person will eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your lamb must be unblemished, a year-old male. You may take it from the sheep or the goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to keep it until the fourteenth day of this month. Then the whole assembly of the Israelite community is to slaughter the lambs at sunset.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall take some of the blood and put it on the two doorposts and the lintel of the houses where they eat the lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night they shall eat the meat that has been roasted over a fire, along with unleavened bread. They shall eat it with bitter herbs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not eat it raw or boiled in water, but roasted over a fire—with its head, its legs, and its internal organs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not leave any of it until the morning. Whatever remains until the morning, you shall burn in the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how you are to eat it: with your cloak tucked into your belt ready for travel, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. Eat it in haste. It is the Lord’s Passover.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For on that night I will pass through the land of Egypt. I will strike down every firstborn in the land of Egypt, both people and animals. Against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgment. I am the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are. When I see the blood, I will pass over you. There will be no plague among you to destroy you when I strike down the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This day shall be a memorial for you, and you are to celebrate it as a festival to the Lord. Throughout your generations you must celebrate it as a permanent regulation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you shall eat unleavened bread. On the first day you must be sure to remove all yeast from your houses, for whoever eats anything leavened from the first day until the seventh day will be cut off from Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the first day you are to have a holy convocation; also on the seventh day there is to be a holy convocation. You shall not do any work, except to prepare what everybody needs to eat. That is all you may do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread, because on this very day I brought your divisions out from the land of Egypt. You shall observe this day throughout your generations as a permanent regulation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month, you shall eat unleavened bread from the evening of the fourteenth day of the month until the evening of the twenty-first day of the month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No yeast is to be found in your houses for seven days, for whoever eats something leavened must be cut off from the Israelite community, whether a foreigner or native-born of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not eat anything leavened. You shall eat unleavened bread in every place you live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses summoned all the elders of Israel and said to them, “Go and take lambs for yourselves according to your family size, and slaughter the Passover lamb.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall take a bundle of hyssop, dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and paint the lintel and the two doorposts with the blood that is in the basin. None of you are to go out of the door of your house until morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord passes through to strike Egypt and sees the blood on the lintel and the two doorposts, the Lord will pass over that door and will not allow the destroyer to enter your houses to strike you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You shall observe these instructions as a perpetual regulation for you and your descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you enter the land that the Lord will give you just as he said he would, you shall observe this ceremony.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when your children ask you, ‘What does this ceremony mean to you?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
you will say, ‘It is the sacrifice of the Passover to the Lord, who passed over the houses of the Israelites in Egypt. When he struck the Egyptians, he spared our houses.’”
The people bowed down and worshipped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites went and did all this. They did just as the Lord had commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At midnight the Lord struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh, who sat on his throne, to the firstborn of the prisoner who was in the dungeon, even all the firstborn of the livestock.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the night Pharaoh got up—he, all his servants, and all the Egyptians—and there was a loud outcry in Egypt, for there was not a house where there was not someone dead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh summoned Moses and Aaron that night and said, “Get up, get away from my people! Both you and the Israelites, go, serve the Lord, as you have said!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take also your flocks and your herds, as you have said, and go! But also bless me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians urged the people to leave the land quickly, for the Egyptians said, “We are all going to die!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites took their dough before it was leavened. They carried their kneading bowls, which were wrapped in their clothing, on their shoulders.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did just as Moses had said, and they asked the Egyptians for articles of silver, articles of gold, and clothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians so that they let the Israelites have what they asked for. In this way they plundered the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites set out from Rameses to Sukkoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides their families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A mixed group of non-Israelites also went up along with them, as well as a large amount of livestock, both flocks and herds.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites baked the dough which they had brought out of Egypt into unleavened loaves, for it had not been leavened, because they had been driven out of Egypt and could not delay. They also had not prepared any provisions for themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The amount of time that the Israelites lived in Egypt was four hundred thirty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of four hundred thirty years, to the very day, all of the Lord’s divisions went out from the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was a night that the Lord kept vigil to bring them out of the land of Egypt. This same night is dedicated to the Lord. All the Israelites are to keep vigil throughout their generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron, “This is the regulation concerning the Passover: No foreigner may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But any slave whom you have purchased may eat it if you circumcise him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A temporary resident or a hired servant may not eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It must be eaten inside one house. You are not to carry any of the meat outside of the house. Do not break any of its bones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole community of Israel shall do this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a resident alien among you wants to observe the Passover to the Lord, every male in his household must be circumcised. Then he may take part in it. He will be treated like a native-born of the land. But no uncircumcised person may eat it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The same law will apply to the native-born and to the alien who resides among you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So that is what all the Israelites did. They did just as the Lord commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That same day the Lord brought the Israelites out of the land of Egypt, lined up by their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Set apart all the firstborn for me, the firstborn of every mother among the Israelites, both people and animals. The firstborn belongs to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses said this to the people:
Remember this day when you came out of Egypt, where you were slaves. For by the strength of his hand the Lord brought you out from there. Nothing with leaven may be eaten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today, in the month of Abib, you are leaving.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So when the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites—the land he swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey—you are to perform this ceremony during this month:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven days you must eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day there is to be a festival to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Unleavened bread must be eaten throughout the seven days. No leavened bread is to be seen among you. No yeast is to be seen among you, anywhere in your entire territory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day you are to explain this to your son, “It is because of what the Lord did for me when I came out of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This will serve as a sign for you on your wrist and a reminder on your forehead so that the law of the Lord may be in your mouth. For with a mighty hand the Lord brought you out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You must keep this regulation at its appointed time from year to year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord brings you into the land of the Canaanites—just as he swore to you and to your fathers—and gives it to you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then you must dedicate the firstborn of every mother to the Lord. Every firstborn of your livestock, the ones that are males, will belong to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every firstborn donkey you are to redeem with a lamb. But if you do not want to redeem it, then you are to break its neck. However, you must redeem all the firstborn among your sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the future, when your son asks you, “What is this about?” you will say to him, “By the strength of his hand the Lord brought us out from Egypt, where we were slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the Lord killed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, the firstborn of people and animals. That is why I sacrifice to the Lord the firstborn of every mother, the males, but I redeem every firstborn of my sons.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It will serve as a sign on your wrist and a symbol on your forehead. For by the strength of his hand the Lord brought us out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them by the way that goes to the land of the Philistines, although it was more direct, for God said, “If the people face war, they may change their minds and return to Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God led the people by the way that goes through the wilderness toward the Red Sea. The Israelites went up from the land of Egypt in battle formation.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses also took the bones of Joseph with him, because Joseph had made the Israelites swear an oath. Joseph had said, “God will surely come to your aid. Then you must bring up my bones with you from Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set out from Sukkoth and camped at Etham on the edge of the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord went in front of them in a pillar of cloud by day to lead them on their way and in a pillar of fire by night to give them light. In this way they could travel by day and by night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pillar of cloud by day and the pillar of fire by night never left its place in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Tell the Israelites to turn back and camp in front of Pi Hahiroth, between Migdol and the sea. They are to camp by the sea, facing Baal Zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Pharaoh will say about the Israelites, ‘They are wandering around in the land. The wilderness has shut them in.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will harden Pharaoh’s heart so that he will pursue them, and I will gain glory through Pharaoh and his entire army. The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord.” So that is what the Israelites did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king of Egypt was told that the people had fled, Pharaoh and his officials had a change of heart concerning the people. They said, “What have we done? We have let Israel go! They will not serve us anymore!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Pharaoh prepared his chariot and took his troops with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also took six hundred of the best chariots and all the other chariots of Egypt with officers over all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, so that he pursued the Israelites. The Israelites were going out defiantly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them. All the horses and chariots of Pharaoh, his charioteers, and his army caught up with them where they were camping by the sea beside Pi Hahiroth, which faces Baal Zephon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Pharaoh approached, the Israelites looked up, and there were the Egyptians marching after them. The Israelites were terrified and cried out to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to Moses, “Was it because there were no graves in Egypt that you took us to die in the wilderness? What have you done to us by bringing us out of Egypt?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Wasn’t this what we said to you in Egypt, ‘Leave us alone. Let us serve the Egyptians’? For it would have been better for us to serve the Egyptians than to die in the wilderness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid. Stand firm, and see the salvation from the Lord, which he will perform for you today. For the Egyptians you see today, you will never see again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will fight for you. You must wait quietly.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Why are you crying out to me? Tell the Israelites to set out.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for you, lift up your staff, stretch out your hand over the sea, and divide the sea so that the Israelites can go through the middle of the sea on dry ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I myself will harden the hearts of the Egyptians so that they will go into the sea after them, and I will gain glory through Pharaoh and his entire army, through his chariots and his charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians will know that I am the Lord, when I have gained glory through Pharaoh, his chariots, and his charioteers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Angel of God, who was going in front of the Israelite forces, moved and went behind them. The pillar of cloud moved from in front of them and stood behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It went between the Egyptian forces and the Israelite forces. The cloud was dark on one side, but it lit up the night on the other. Neither group approached the other all night long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and all night long the Lord drove the sea back with a strong east wind and turned the sea into dry land. The waters were divided.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites went into the middle of the sea on dry ground. The waters were like a wall for them on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Egyptians pursued them, and all of Pharaoh’s horses, his chariots, and his charioteers went after them into the middle of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During the last watch of the night, the Lord looked down on the Egyptian forces from the pillar of fire and cloud. Then he confused the Egyptian forces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He jammed their chariot wheels, and they had difficulty driving them. The Egyptians said, “We must flee from Israel, for the Lord is fighting for them against Egypt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Stretch out your hand over the sea, and the waters will come back over the Egyptians, over their chariots and their charioteers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses stretched out his hand over the sea, and at daybreak the sea returned to its normal place. While the Egyptians were fleeing from it, the Lord threw the Egyptians into the middle of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The waters came back and covered the chariots and the charioteers, the entire army of Pharaoh that went into the sea after the Israelites. Not even one of them survived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the Israelites went through the middle of the sea on dry land, and the waters were like a wall for them on their right and on their left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day the Lord saved Israel from the hand of the Egyptians, and Israel saw the Egyptians dead on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel saw the mighty hand which the Lord put into action against the Egyptians, and the people feared the Lord and believed in the Lord and in Moses, his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses and the Israelites sang this song to the Lord. They said:
I will sing to the Lord, for he is highly exalted.
The horse and its rider he has thrown into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is my strength and song.
He has become my salvation.
This is my God, and I will praise him;
my father’s God, and I will exalt him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord is a warrior.
The Lord is his name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He has cast Pharaoh’s chariots and his army into the sea.
His elite officers are drowned in the Red Sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The deep waters covered them.
They sank down to the depths like a stone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lord, your right hand is glorious in power.
Lord, your right hand has shattered the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In your great majesty you overthrew those who opposed you.
You sent out your burning anger.
It consumed them like stubble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
At the blast from your nostrils the waters piled up.
The flowing waters stood up like a dam.
The deep waters became solid in the heart of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The enemy said, “I will pursue.
I will overtake. I will divide the plunder.
I will do whatever I want with them.
I will draw my sword,
and my hand will destroy them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But you blew with your breath,
and the sea covered them.
They sank like lead in the mighty waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Lord, who is like you among the gods?
Who is like you, glorious in holiness,
awesome in praise, working wonders?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You stretched out your right hand,
and the earth swallowed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In your mercy you will lead the people that you have redeemed.
In your strength you will guide them to your holy pastureland.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The nations will hear and tremble.
Anguish will grip the inhabitants of Philistia.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the chiefs of Edom will be terrified.
Trembling will seize the leaders of Moab.
All the inhabitants of Canaan will melt away in despair.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Terror and dread will fall upon them.
By the great power of your arm they will be as still as stone
    until your people pass by, O Lord,
    until the people whom you have purchased pass by.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You will bring them in and plant them
    on the mountain that belongs to you,
    the place, O Lord, that you have made for your dwelling,
    the sanctuary, O Lord, that your hands have established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will reign forever and ever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Pharaoh’s horses along with his chariots and charioteers went into the sea, the Lord brought the waters of the sea back on them, but the Israelites walked on dry land in the middle of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Miriam the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a hand drum, and all the women followed her with drums and dancing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Miriam sang to them,
Sing to the Lord, for he is highly exalted.
The horse and its rider he has thrown into the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses led Israel on from the Red Sea, and they went out to the Wilderness of Shur. They traveled for three days in the wilderness but found no water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they came to Marah, they were not able to drink the waters of Marah, because they were bitter. That is why they named the place Marah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people grumbled against Moses, and they said, “What will we drink?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Moses cried out to the Lord, and the Lord showed him some wood. Moses threw it into the water, and the water became fit to drink.
There the Lord made a decree and ruling for them, and there he tested them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said, “If only you would listen to the voice of the Lord your God, and do what is right in his eyes, and pay attention to his commandments, and keep all his regulations, I would not place on you any of the diseases that I placed on the Egyptians, for I am the Lord, who heals you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they came to Elim where there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they camped there by the waters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fifteenth day of the second month after they had left the land of Egypt, the entire Israelite community set out from Elim and came to the Wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire Israelite community grumbled against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites said to them, “If only we had died by the Lord’s hand in the land of Egypt, when we sat around pots of meat and ate as much food as we wanted, but now you have brought us out into this wilderness to have this whole community die of hunger.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Watch what I will do. I will rain down bread from heaven for you, and the people will go out each day and gather enough for that day. In this way I will test whether they will follow my instructions or not.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day they will prepare what they bring in, and it will be twice as much as they gather on the other days.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses and Aaron said to all the Israelites, “At evening you will know that it was the Lord who brought you out of the land of Egypt,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and in the morning you will see the Glory of the Lord, because he has heard your constant grumbling against the Lord. Who are we that you should grumble against us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Now the Lord will give you meat to eat in the evening and as much bread as you want in the morning, because the Lord has heard your grumbling against him. Who are we? Your grumbling is not against us but against the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Tell the entire Israelite community, ‘Come before the Lord, because he has heard your grumbling.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Aaron spoke to the entire Israelite community, they turned toward the wilderness, and suddenly the Glory of the Lord appeared in the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I have heard the grumbling of the Israelites. Say to them, ‘At evening you will eat meat, and in the morning you will eat bread until you are full. Then you will know that I am the Lord your God.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So in the evening quail came and covered the camp, and in the morning a layer of dew surrounded the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the layer of dew was gone, there were thin flakes on the surface of the wilderness, thin as frost on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When the Israelites saw it, they said to one another, “What is it?” because they did not know what it was.
Moses said to them, “This is the bread which the Lord has given to you as food to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what the Lord has commanded: All of them are to gather as much of it as they need to eat. You are to take an omer per person based on the number of people each of you has in your tents.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites did this, and some gathered more, some less.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they measured it with an omer, the one who gathered more did not have too much, and the one who gathered less did not have too little. All of them gathered as much as they needed to eat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to them, “No one is to leave any of it until morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, they did not listen to Moses. Some of them left part of it until morning, and it became full of worms and stank. So Moses was angry with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gathered it each morning. All of them gathered as much as they needed to eat. When the sun grew hot, it melted away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the sixth day they gathered twice as much food, two omers for each person, and all the leaders of the community came and reported to Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “This is what the Lord has said: Tomorrow is a complete rest, a holy sabbath to the Lord. Bake what you want to bake, and boil what you want to boil, but set aside for yourselves all the rest of it to be kept until morning.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set it aside until morning as Moses commanded, and it did not stink, and there were no worms in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “Today eat whatever is left over, for today is a sabbath to the Lord. Today you will not find any around the camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six days you will gather it, but on the seventh day, the Sabbath, there will not be any.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the seventh day some of the people went out to gather it, but they did not find any.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will you people refuse to keep my commandments and my instructions?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, the Lord has given you the Sabbath. Therefore on the sixth day he will give you two days’ worth of bread. All of you are to stay where you are. None of you are to leave your places on the seventh day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the people rested on the seventh day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The house of Israel called it manna. It looked like white coriander seed, and it tasted like wafers made with honey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said, “This is what the Lord has commanded: A full omer of it is to be kept throughout your generations so that they may see the bread which I fed you in the wilderness when I brought you out of the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
