verses.text: Moses said to Aaron, “Take a container, and put a full omer of manna in it. Place it before the Lord, to be kept throughout your generations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To obey the Lord’s command to Moses, Aaron placed an omer before the Testimony, to be preserved.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites ate manna for forty years, until they came to a land that was inhabited. They ate manna until they came to the border of the land of Canaan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (An omer, by the way, is one-tenth of an ephah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entire Israelite community set out on their journey from the Wilderness of Sin as the Lord had commanded. They camped at Rephidim, but there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the people quarreled with Moses and said, “Give us water to drink.”
Moses said to them, “Why are you quarreling with me? Why are you testing the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people were thirsty for water there, so they grumbled against Moses. They said, “Why did you ever bring us up out of Egypt to let us, our children, and our livestock die of thirst?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses cried out to the Lord, “What shall I do with these people? They are almost ready to stone me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go in front of the people, and take the elders of Israel with you. Also take in your hand the staff with which you struck the Nile, and go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Watch me. I will stand there in front of you on the rock in Horeb. You are to strike the rock. Water will come out of it, and the people will drink.” Moses did that in the sight of the elders of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He named the place Massah and Meribah, because the Israelites quarreled, and because they tested the Lord by saying, “Is the Lord among us or not?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Amalekites came and fought against the Israelites at Rephidim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to Joshua, “Select some men for us, and go out and fight against the Amalekites. Tomorrow I will stand on the hilltop, and God’s staff will be in my hand.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Joshua did just as Moses told him.
While Joshua was fighting against the Amalekites, Moses, Aaron, and Hur went up to the hilltop.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever Moses held up his hand, the Israelites would start winning, but whenever he lowered his hand, the Amalekites would start winning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses’ arms became tired, they took a stone and placed it under him, and he sat on it. Aaron and Hur held up his hands—one on one side, and one on the other side. In this way his hands were steady until sunset.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Joshua defeated the Amalekite army with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord then said to Moses, “Write this on a scroll as a memorial, and make sure that Joshua hears it, because I will completely erase the memory of the Amalekites from under heaven.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses built an altar and named it “The Lord Is My Banner,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because he had said, “Since a hand was raised against the throne of the Lord, the Lord will be at war with the Amalekites from generation to generation.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now Moses’ father-in-law Jethro, priest of Midian, heard about everything that God had done for Moses and for his people Israel and how the Lord had brought Israel out of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Moses had sent his wife Zipporah away, his father-in-law Jethro had taken her in,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: along with her two sons. The name of one son was Gershom, for Moses had said, “I have become an alien in a foreign land.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The name of the other was Eliezer, for he had said, “My father’s God was my helper, and he has delivered me from Pharaoh’s sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses’ father-in-law Jethro, Moses’ sons, and his wife were coming to Moses in the wilderness where he had camped at the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent word to Moses, “I, your father-in-law Jethro, your wife, and her two sons are coming to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went out to meet his father-in-law, and he bowed down and kissed him. They asked each other how they had been, and they went into the tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses told his father-in-law about everything that the Lord had done to Pharaoh and the Egyptians for Israel’s sake, about all the hardships that had confronted them along the way, and how the Lord had delivered them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro rejoiced over all the good things that the Lord had done for Israel when he delivered them from the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro said, “Blessed be the Lord, who has delivered you from the hand of the Egyptians and the hand of Pharaoh. Blessed be the Lord, who has delivered the people out of the hand of the Egyptians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I know that the Lord is greater than all gods because he did this to those who acted arrogantly against the Israelites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jethro, Moses’ father-in-law, brought a burnt offering and sacrifices to God. Aaron and all the elders of Israel came to eat a meal with Moses’ father-in-law in the presence of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The next day Moses sat down to serve as a judge for the people, and the people stood around Moses from morning till evening.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Moses’ father-in-law saw everything that he did for the people, he said, “What is this that you are doing for the people? Why do you alone sit as judge with all the people standing around you from morning till evening?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to his father-in-law, “Because the people come to me to inquire of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever there is a dispute between them, they come to me, and I judge between the two sides, and I reveal the regulations of God and his laws.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses’ father-in-law said to him, “What you are doing is not good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will certainly wear out both yourself and these people who are with you, for the work is too much for you. You are not able to handle this alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to me now. I will give you advice, and may God be with you. Represent the people before God, and bring their disputes to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instruct them about the regulations and laws, and show them the way they are to live and the things that they are to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you should select capable men from among all the people, God-fearing, trustworthy men, who hate dishonest gain. Then place them over the people as officials over groups of a thousand, a hundred, fifty, or ten.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Have them judge all the disputes of the people at the first level. They can refer any difficult case to you, but every easy case they can judge themselves. Make your load lighter; they can carry it with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you will do this, and God so commands you, then you will be able to endure, and all these people will also return home satisfied.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses listened to his father-in-law and did everything that he had said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses chose capable men from all of Israel and made them leaders over the people: officials over thousands, hundreds, fifties, and tens.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They judged all the cases of the people initially. They brought the difficult cases to Moses, but every easy case they judged themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses sent his father-in-law on his way, and he returned to his own land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third month after the Israelites had left the land of Egypt, on that same day of the month, they came to the Wilderness of Sinai.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After they set out from Rephidim and came to the Wilderness of Sinai, they camped in the wilderness. Israel camped there in front of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went up to God, and the Lord called to him from the mountain, “This is what you are to say to the house of Jacob and to tell the people of Israel:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘You have seen what I did to the Egyptians and how I carried you on eagles’ wings and brought you to myself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now if you will carefully listen to my voice and keep my covenant, then you will be my special treasure out of all the nations, although the entire earth is mine.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will be my kingdom of priests and my holy nation.’ These are the words that you are to speak to the Israelites.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went and summoned the elders of the people, and he set before them all these words that the Lord had commanded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All the people answered together, “Everything that the Lord has said, we will do.”
Moses brought back the people’s words to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Look, I will come to you in a dense cloud so that the people will hear when I speak with you, and then they will always believe you.” Moses told the people’s words to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go to the people. Consecrate them today and tomorrow, and have them wash their clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be ready by the third day, for on the third day the Lord will come down on Mount Sinai in the sight of all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall set boundaries for the people all around the mountain. Tell them: ‘Be careful that you do not go up onto the mountain or touch the edge of it.’ Whoever touches the mountain must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one’s hand is to touch such a person, but that person is to be stoned to death or shot with arrows. No such animal or person shall be allowed to live. But when the special ram’s horn sounds a long blast, the people may come up to the mountain.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went down from the mountain to the people. He consecrated the people, and they washed their clothes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the people, “Be ready by the third day. Do not come near a woman.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the third day, when morning came, there was thunder and lightning. A thick cloud was over the mountain, and there was a very loud blast of a ram’s horn. All the people in the camp trembled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses brought the people out of the camp to meet God, and they stood at the foot of the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Mount Sinai was covered with smoke, because the Lord descended on it in fire. Its smoke went up like the smoke from a kiln, and the whole mountain trembled violently.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the sound of the ram’s horn grew louder and louder, Moses spoke, and God answered him in the thunder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord came down on Mount Sinai, at the top of the mountain. The Lord then called Moses to the top of the mountain, and Moses went up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Go down and warn the people not to break through to see the Lord. If they do, many of them will fall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even the priests, who approach the Lord, must consecrate themselves so that the Lord does not break out against them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the Lord, “The people cannot come up to Mount Sinai, because you warned, ‘Set boundaries around the mountain and treat it as holy.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to him, “Go down and bring Aaron up with you, but the priests and the people must not break through to come up to the Lord, so that the Lord will not break out against them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Moses went down to the people and told them these things.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then God spoke all these words:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out from the land of Egypt, where you were slaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall have no other gods beside me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not make any carved image for yourself or a likeness of anything in heaven above, or on the earth below, or in the waters under the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not bow down to them or be subservient to them, for I the Lord your God am a jealous God. I follow up on the guilt of the fathers with their children, their grandchildren, and their great-grandchildren, if they also hate me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I show mercy to thousands who love me and keep my commandments.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not misuse the name of the Lord your God, for the Lord will not permit anyone who misuses his name to escape unpunished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Remember the Sabbath day by setting it apart as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six days you are to serve and do all your regular work,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but the seventh day shall be a sabbath rest to the Lord your God. Do not do any regular work, neither you, nor your sons or daughters, nor your male or female servants, nor your cattle, nor the alien who is residing inside your gates,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for in six days the Lord made the heavens and the earth, the sea, and everything that is in them, but he rested on the seventh day. In this way the Lord blessed the seventh day and made it holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Honor your father and your mother so that you may spend many days on the land that the Lord your God is giving to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not commit murder.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not commit adultery.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not steal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not give false testimony against your neighbor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not covet your neighbor’s house. You shall not covet your neighbor’s wife, his male servant, his female servant, his ox, his donkey, or anything else that belongs to your neighbor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people saw and heard the thunder and the lightning and the sound of the ram’s horn and the mountain smoking. The people saw, and they trembled and stood far away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they said to Moses, “Speak with us yourself, and we will listen, but do not let God speak with us, or we will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses said to the people, “Do not be afraid, for God has come to test you, so that you may always fear him, so that you do not sin.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people stayed at a distance, but Moses approached the thick darkness where God was.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord told Moses to tell the people of Israel the following things:
You yourselves have seen that I have talked with you from heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not make gods of silver or gods of gold and place them beside me. You shall not make them for yourselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to make an altar of earth for me and to sacrifice your whole burnt offerings on it, as well as your fellowship offerings, your sheep, and your cattle. In every place where I cause my name to be remembered, I will come to you and I will bless you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you make a stone altar for me, you are not to build it out of cut stones, because by applying a tool to it you would pollute it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are not to go up to my altar by steps, so that your nakedness will not be uncovered upon it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now these are the ordinances which you are to set before them:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you purchase a Hebrew servant, he is to serve for six years, but in the seventh he may go free without paying anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he comes in by himself, he will go out by himself. If he is married when he comes in, then his wife will go out with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If his master gives him a wife and she bears him sons or daughters, the wife and her children will belong to her master, and the servant will go out by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the servant formally declares, “I love my master, my wife, and my children. I do not want to go out free,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then his master shall bring him to the judges. His master shall bring him to the door or to the doorpost, and he shall bore through his ear with an awl. Then he shall serve him for the rest of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man sells his daughter to be a female servant, she may not be sent out of the household as the male servants may be.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If she does not please her master who has married her, then he must let her be redeemed. He has no right to sell her to a foreign people, since he has not kept his commitment to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he marries her to his son, he must deal with her as he would deal with a daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he takes a second wife for himself, he must not diminish the food, the clothing, or the marital rights of the first wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he does not do these three things for her, she may go free without paying any money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who strikes a man so that he dies must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if this was not done intentionally but rather was an act of God, for that kind of case I will appoint a place among you to which that man can flee.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if a man plots and kills his neighbor deliberately, you shall take him from my altar, so that he may be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who strikes his father or his mother must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If anyone kidnaps someone and sells him, or if the kidnapped person is found in his possession, the kidnapper must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Anyone who curses his father or his mother must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If men quarrel and one strikes the other with a stone or with his fist, and the victim does not die but is confined to bed—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: if the victim gets up and can walk around outside with his staff, then the one who struck him shall not be punished, but he must pay for the victim’s lost work time while he is recuperating, until he is completely healed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man strikes his male or his female servant with a club, and the servant dies at his hand, he must certainly be punished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, if the servant gets up after a day or two, the man shall not be punished, for the servant was his property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If men are fighting and they injure a pregnant woman so that the child comes out, yet no harm follows, they must certainly be fined as much as the woman’s husband demands and the judges approve.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if any harm follows, then you are to take life for life,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: burn for burn, wound for wound, and bruise for bruise.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man strikes his male or female servant’s eye and destroys it, he must let the servant go free as payment for the eye.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If he knocks out his male or female servant’s tooth, he must let the servant go free as payment for the tooth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If an ox gores a man or a woman to death, the ox must be stoned to death, and its flesh must not be eaten, but the owner of the ox will not be held responsible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the ox, however, had a habit of goring in the past, and its owner had been warned, but he did not keep it confined, and it then kills a man or a woman, the ox shall be stoned, and its owner shall also be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if a redemption payment is imposed on the owner instead of the death penalty, he must pay whatever is imposed on him to save his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is also the ruling that applies to him if the ox has gored someone’s son or daughter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if the ox gores a male servant or a female servant, thirty shekels of silver shall be given to the servant’s owner, and the ox is to be stoned to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man uncovers a cistern, or if a man digs a cistern and does not cover it, and an ox or a donkey falls into it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the owner of the cistern shall pay for the loss in full. He shall give money to the owner of the animal, and the dead animal shall be his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If one man’s ox injures his neighbor’s ox, so that it dies, they shall sell the live ox and divide the money they got for it, and they shall also divide the dead animal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if it was known that the ox was in the habit of goring in the past, and its owner has not kept it confined, he must pay ox for ox, and the dead animal will be his.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man steals an ox or a sheep and butchers it or sells it, he shall pay five oxen for an ox and four sheep for a sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a thief is caught breaking in and is struck so that he dies, the one who kills him shall not be guilty of bloodshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if this takes place after sunrise, the one who kills him shall be guilty of bloodshed.
A thief shall make restitution. If he has nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the stolen animal found in his possession is alive, whether it is an ox, donkey, or sheep, he shall repay double.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man is grazing livestock in a field or a vineyard, and he lets his animals run loose and they graze in another man’s field, ⎣he shall make restitution from his own field on the basis of the produce that was eaten, but if they have grazed over the whole field,⎦ he shall make restitution from the best of his own field and from the best of his own vineyard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a fire gets out of control and spreads through the thorn bushes so that someone else’s shocks of grain, standing grain, or grain field are consumed, the one who lit the fire must certainly make restitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man entrusts money or other items to his neighbor for safekeeping, and they are stolen out of that man’s house, if the thief is found, he shall repay double.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If the thief is not found, then the owner of the house shall appear before the judges to find out whether he has laid his hands on his neighbor’s goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In every such offense, whether it involves an ox, a donkey, a sheep, clothing, or any other kind of lost property about which someone claims, “This is mine,” the claims of both parties shall be presented before the judges. Whichever party the judges find guilty shall repay double to his neighbor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man entrusts a donkey, an ox, a sheep, or any animal to his neighbor for safekeeping, and it dies or is injured or is driven off, and no one sees what happened,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: to settle the matter between them, the man who received the property must make an oath to the Lord that he has not laid his hands on his neighbor’s goods. Its owner must accept the oath, and the man who received the property shall not be required to make restitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if, in fact, it was stolen while in his custody, he shall make restitution to its owner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If it was torn in pieces by animals, let him bring it for evidence. He is not required to make good that which was torn.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man borrows anything from his neighbor, and it is injured or dies while its owner is not with it, the borrower must certainly make restitution.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If its owner is with it, the borrower will not be required to make restitution. If it was rented, the rent covers the loss.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If a man seduces a virgin who is not pledged in marriage and lies down with her, he must pay a bride price for her to be his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If her father flatly refuses to give her to him, the offender still must weigh out silver equivalent to the bride price for virgins.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not allow a sorceress to live.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever lies down with an animal shall certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever sacrifices to any god, except to the Lord alone, shall be devoted to destruction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not wrong a resident alien or oppress him, for you were aliens in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not take advantage of any widow or fatherless child.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take advantage of them in any way, and they make even the faintest cry to me, I will surely hear their cry,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and my anger will burn, and I will kill you with the sword, and your wives will be widows, and your children fatherless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you lend money to anyone among my people who is poor, you must not act like a moneylender. You must not charge him interest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you take your neighbor’s outer garment as collateral, you must restore it to him before the sun goes down,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for his garment is the only cover he has for his skin. What would he sleep in? Be assured that when he cries to me, I will hear, for I am gracious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not malign the judges, nor curse a ruler of your people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You shall not delay bringing offerings from your abundant harvest and from your overflowing wine vats.
You shall present the firstborn of your sons to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall do the same with your cattle and with your sheep. For seven days a newborn animal shall be with its mother. Then on the eighth day you shall present it to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to be men set apart as holy for me. So you shall not eat any flesh that is torn by wild animals. You shall cast it to the dogs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not spread a false report. Do not join hands with the wicked to be a malicious witness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not follow a crowd to do evil. Do not go along with the crowd by testifying in court to pervert justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not show favoritism to a poor man in his lawsuit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you come upon your enemy’s ox or his donkey going astray, you certainly must bring it back to him again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you see that the donkey of someone who hates you has fallen down under its load, do not pass him by. You certainly must help him with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not deny justice to the poor people among you in their lawsuits.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep your distance from a false charge. Do not put those who are innocent and those who are righteous to death, for I will not acquit the wicked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not accept a bribe, for a bribe blinds those who have sight and distorts the words of the righteous.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not oppress a resident alien, for you know how it feels to be an alien, because you were aliens in the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six years you shall sow your land and gather in its produce,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but during the seventh year you are to let it rest and lie fallow, so that the needy among your people may eat, and the animals in the fields can eat what they leave. You are to deal with your vineyard and with your olive grove in the same way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six days you shall do your work, and on the seventh day you shall rest, so that your ox and your donkey will have rest, and so that the son of your female servant and the resident alien will be refreshed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Be careful to do all the things that I have said to you. Do not mention the name of other gods. Do not let their names come out of your mouth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times a year you shall observe pilgrimage festivals for me:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall observe the Festival of Unleavened Bread. For seven days you shall eat bread without yeast, as I commanded you, at the appointed time in the month of Abib (for during that month you came out from Egypt). No one is to appear before me empty-handed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Next observe the Festival of Reaping by presenting the first ripe produce of your labors, which you sow in the field.
Finally, observe the Festival of Ingathering, at the end of the year, when you pick the fruits of your labors from the fields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times a year all your males shall appear before the Lord God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not offer any bread made with yeast together with the blood of my sacrifices. None of the fat from my festival shall remain until morning.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The very first produce from your soil you shall bring into the house of the Lord your God.
You shall not boil a baby goat in its mother’s milk.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look, I will send an angel before you to guard you on your way and to bring you into the place which I have prepared.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pay attention to him. Listen to his voice. Do not provoke him, because he will not pardon your disobedience, for my Name is in him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if you carefully listen to his voice and carry out all that I speak, then I will be an enemy to your enemies and an adversary to your adversaries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, my Angel shall go ahead of you and bring you into the territory of the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Canaanites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites. Then I will cut them off.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not bow down to their gods. Do not serve them or follow their practices, but you must completely overthrow them and demolish their sacred memorial stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall serve the Lord your God, and he will bless your bread and your water, and I will take sickness away from your midst.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one will miscarry or be childless in your land. I will grant you the full number of your days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send my terror before you, and I will spread confusion among all the people to whom you come, and I will make all your enemies turn their backs and flee from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will send the hornet ahead of you. It will drive out the Hivites, the Canaanites, and the Hittites from your presence.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will not drive them out from before you in a single year, or the land would become desolate, and the wild animals would become too numerous for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As you advance, I will drive them out little by little, until you have grown in number and taken possession of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will establish your border from the Red Sea all the way to the Mediterranean Sea, and from the Wilderness to the River. So I will deliver the inhabitants of the land into your hand, and you will drive them out before you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall not make a treaty with them or with their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are not to dwell in your land, or they will make you sin against me, because if you serve their gods, this will surely be a trap for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Come up to the Lord, you and Aaron, along with Nadab and Abihu and seventy of the elders of Israel, and worship me from a distance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Only Moses is allowed to come near the Lord, but the others are not to come near, and the people are not to go up with him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses came and reported to the people all the words of the Lord and all the ordinances. Then all the people answered with one voice and said, “All the words which the Lord has spoken we will do.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Moses wrote down all the words of the Lord.
He got up early in the morning and built an altar at the foot of the mountain. He set up twelve memorial stones for the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent young Israelite men, who offered whole burnt offerings and sacrificed fellowship offerings of cattle to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took half of the blood and put it in bowls, and he splashed half of the blood on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the Book of the Covenant and read it out loud to the people and they said, “All that the Lord has spoken we will do. We will obey.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses took the blood and splashed it on the people. He said, “Look, here is the blood of the covenant, which the Lord made with you by means of all these words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Moses, Aaron, Nadab, Abihu, and seventy of the elders of Israel went up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They saw the God of Israel. Under his feet they saw what looked like a pavement of sapphire as clear as the sky.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord did not lay his hand on the dignitaries of the people of Israel. They gazed at God, and they ate and drank.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Come up to me on the mountain. Wait there, and I will give you the stone tablets with the law and the commands that I have written, so that you can teach them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses set out with his assistant Joshua and went up onto the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the elders, “Wait here for us, until we come back to you. Look, here are Aaron and Hur. They will be with you. Whoever is involved in a dispute can go to them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses went up onto the mountain, and the cloud covered the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Glory of the Lord settled on Mount Sinai, and the cloud covered the mountain for six days. On the seventh day the Lord called to Moses out of the middle of the cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The appearance of the Glory of the Lord looked like a devouring fire on the top of the mountain in the sight of the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Moses entered into the middle of the cloud and climbed up the mountain. Moses was on the mountain forty days and forty nights.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Speak to the people of Israel so that they gather a special offering for me. From everyone whose heart makes him willing you shall gather the offering for me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the offering which you are to gather from them: gold, silver, and bronze;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: blue, purple, and scarlet material, fine linen; goats’ hair,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: rams’ skins dyed red, and hides of sea cows; acacia wood,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: olive oil for the Light, spices for the anointing oil and for the fragrant incense,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: onyx stones, and stones to be mounted on the special vest and on the pouch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to make a sanctuary for me, so that I may dwell among them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to make it exactly according to the design for the Dwelling and the designs for all of its furniture which I will show you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall make an ark of acacia wood. It is to be forty-five inches long, twenty-seven inches wide, and twenty-seven inches high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold. Overlay it on the inside and the outside, and make a gold border around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Cast four gold rings for it and place them next to its four feet. Two rings are for one side of it, and two rings for the other side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the poles which are used to carry the ark into the rings on the sides of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles are to be placed into the rings on the ark. They are not to be removed from the rings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the Testimony, which I am about to give to you, into the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make an atonement seat of pure gold, forty-five inches long and twenty-seven inches wide.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two cherubim of hammered gold. You are to make them for the two ends of the atonement seat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make one cherub for one end and one cherub for the other end. The cherubim on its two ends are to form one piece with the atonement seat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The cherubim will spread their wings upward so that they cover the atonement seat with their wings, and they will face each other. The faces of the cherubim are to be looking inward toward the atonement seat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the atonement seat on top of the ark, and put the Testimony, which I will give to you, into the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There I will meet with you, and from above the atonement seat, from between the two cherubim that are on the Ark of the Testimony, I will communicate to you all the commands that I will give to you for the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a table of acacia wood, thirty-six inches long, eighteen inches wide, and twenty-seven inches high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold and make a gold border around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a three-inch rim around it. Make a gold border for its rim all the way around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make four gold rings for it and fasten the rings to the four corners, above the four legs of the table.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rings shall be close to the border to hold the poles used to carry the table.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the poles of acacia wood and overlay them with gold, so that the table can be carried with them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to make its dishes, its small bowls, its pitchers, and its larger bowls to pour out offerings. Make them of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to set the Bread of the Presence on the table so that it is in front of me at all times.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a lampstand of pure gold. The lampstand is to be made of hammered metal. Its pedestal, its shaft, its cups, its buds, and its flowers are all to be formed as one piece with the lampstand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are to be six branches going out from its two sides: Three branches of the lampstand are to go out from one side, and three branches of the lampstand are to go out from the other side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are to be three cups shaped like almond blossoms with buds and flowers on the first branch, and three cups like almond blossoms with buds and flowers on the branch opposite it. All six branches going out from the lampstand are to be the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the lampstand itself make four cups shaped like almond blossoms with buds and flowers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bud under one pair of branches is to form one piece with the lampstand, and the bud under the second pair of branches is to form one piece with the lampstand, and the bud under the third pair of branches is to form one piece with the lampstand—the same for all six branches going out of the lampstand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its buds and branches are to be made as one piece with it. All of it will be one hammered piece of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make seven lamps for it, and these lamps shall be lit to give light to the area in front of the lampstand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Its wick trimmers and its pans are to be made of pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be made of seventy-five pounds of pure gold with all these accessories.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: See to it that you make them according to their design, which is being shown to you on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The curtain that forms the dwelling itself you shall make with ten panels of fine woven linen, with blue, purple, and scarlet material. Decorate them with cherubim, which are to be the work of a skillful craftsman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of each panel of the curtain is to be forty-two feet, and the width of each panel six feet. All the panels are to be the same size.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Five panels of the curtain are to be connected together into one panel, and the other five panels are to be connected together into one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Attach blue loops to the edge of the last panel in the first set of curtains. In the same way attach loops to the edge of the last panel of the second set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make fifty loops for the edge of the first set of curtains, and make fifty loops for the edge of the second set of curtains. The loops are to be opposite one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make fifty gold clasps, and connect the two sets of curtains to each other with the clasps, so that the dwelling becomes one connected piece.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make panels for a curtain made from goats’ hair to serve as a tent over the dwelling. Make eleven panels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of each panel is to be forty-five feet, and the width of each panel six feet. The eleven panels are to be the same size.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Connect five panels of the curtain into one unit, and connect six panels into another unit. Fold the sixth panel of the curtain over the front edge of the Tent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Attach fifty loops to the edge of the last panel of one set of curtains, and fifty loops to the edge of the last panel in the second set.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make fifty bronze clasps, and put the clasps into the loops to join the two pieces of the tent together, so that it forms one unit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The excess part of the curtains that form the tent, which is left over, that is, the half curtain that is extra, is to hang down over the back of the Dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The eighteen inches left over on one side and the eighteen inches left over on the other side, all along the length of the tent coverings, are to be left hanging down over the sides of the Dwelling on either side to cover it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall also make a covering for the tent made from rams’ skins dyed red and a covering made from hides of sea cows to go above that one.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make upright boards of acacia wood to serve as a framework for the Dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of each board is to be fifteen feet, and the width of each board is to be twenty-seven inches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are to be two pegs on each board for connecting them to the next board. That is the way you are to make all the boards for the Dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Make these boards for the Dwelling:
Make twenty boards for the south side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make forty socket bases of silver to be placed under the twenty boards—two sockets to go under the first board to hold its two pegs, and two sockets to go under the next board for its two pegs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the second side of the Dwelling, the north side, make twenty boards,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: with forty socket bases of silver—two sockets to go under the first board, and two sockets to go under the next board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the far side of the Dwelling, the west side, make six boards.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then make two boards for each of the back corners of the Dwelling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the two corners there are to be twin boards from the bottom to the top, but they are to be joined at the top by one ring—both cornerpieces are to be made like this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Altogether there will be eight boards with silver socket bases, sixteen socket bases—two socket bases to go under each board.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make crossbars of acacia wood—five crossbars for the boards on one side of the Dwelling,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: five crossbars for the boards on the other side of the Dwelling, and five crossbars for the boards on the backside of the Dwelling on the west.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The middle bar, placed halfway up the boards, shall pass through from one end of the boards to the other end.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay the boards with gold. Attach gold rings to them to hold the crossbars, and overlay the crossbars with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall set up the Dwelling according to the design that is being shown to you on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a special veil of blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen, decorated with cherubim. It shall be made as the work of a skillful craftsman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hang it on four posts of acacia wood overlaid with gold, which stand on four socket bases of silver. The hooks are to be made of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hang up the veil below the spot where the clasps join the two parts of the dwelling. Then bring the Ark of the Testimony inside the veil. The veil shall separate the Holy Place from the Most Holy Place for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall put the atonement seat on top of the Ark of the Testimony in the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall set the table outside the veil, and the lampstand opposite the table on the south side of the Dwelling. You shall put the table on the north side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a screen for the entry to the tent from blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen, the work of an embroiderer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make five posts of acacia wood to support the screen, and overlay them with gold. Their hooks shall be gold, and you shall cast five bronze socket bases for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make the altar of acacia wood, seven and a half feet long and seven and a half feet wide. The altar shall be square, and it shall be four and a half feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make horns on its four corners. These horns are to be made as one piece with the altar, and you are to overlay the altar with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make pails to take away its fat-drenched ashes. Make shovels, basins, meat hooks, and fire pans for the altar. Make all its utensils of bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make a grate for it which is a latticework of bronze, and make four bronze rings for the four corners of the latticework grate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Set the grate in place below the top edge of the altar, so that the grate rests halfway down from the top of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make poles for the altar, poles of acacia wood, and overlay them with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These poles are to be put through the rings on the two sides of the altar whenever it is carried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You are to make the altar hollow, with sides made of boards. They are to make it as it is being shown to you on the mountain.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You shall make the courtyard for the Dwelling.
For the south side of the courtyard there shall be hangings of fine woven linen, one hundred fifty feet long for that side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There shall be twenty posts for it, and their twenty socket bases shall be bronze. The hooks for the posts and the connectors shall be silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the same way, for the north side there shall be hangings one hundred fifty feet long, with twenty posts and twenty bronze socket bases. The hooks for the posts and their connectors shall be silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the courtyard on the west side there shall be hangings seventy-five feet wide, with ten posts and ten socket bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The width of the courtyard on the east side shall be seventy-five feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The hangings on one side of the entry gate shall be twenty-two feet six inches wide with three posts and three socket bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the other side there shall be hangings twenty-two feet six inches wide with three posts and three socket bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the entryway into the courtyard there shall be a screen thirty feet wide, made of blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen, the work of an embroiderer. Make four posts for it and four socket bases.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the posts around the courtyard shall be connected with silver. Their hooks shall be silver, and their socket bases bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The length of the courtyard shall be one hundred fifty feet, and the width seventy-five feet on both ends. The height of the hangings of fine woven linen shall be seven and a half feet. Its socket bases shall be bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the utensils for all the services of the Dwelling, all its tent stakes, and all the stakes for the courtyard shall be bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall command the people of Israel to bring you pure oil from beaten olives for the Light so that the lamp may burn every night.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the Tent of Meeting, in front of the veil which is in front of the Testimony, Aaron and his sons shall tend the lamp before the Lord from evening to morning. This shall be a permanent regulation throughout their generations for the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring Aaron your brother near to you from among the people of Israel, and his sons with him, so that he may minister to me in the priest’s office. Bring Aaron and Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar, Aaron’s sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make holy garments for Aaron your brother to give him honor and splendor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Speak to all the skilled craftsmen, whom I have filled with the spirit of wisdom, so that they make Aaron’s garments to consecrate him, so that he may minister to me in the priest’s office.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These are the garments which they shall make: a chest pouch, a special vest, a robe, a specially woven tunic, a turban, and a sash. They shall make holy garments for Aaron your brother and for his sons, so that he may minister to me in the priest’s office.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The craftsmen shall use the gold, and the blue, purple, and scarlet material, and the fine linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall make the special vest of gold and of blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen, the work of a skillful craftsman.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to have two shoulder straps, one on each side, so that the vest can be fastened together.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The decorated band, which is attached to the vest, is to be just like it: made of gold, and of blue, purple, and scarlet material and of fine woven linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take two onyx stones and engrave the names of the sons of Israel on them—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: six of their names on one stone and the names of the other six on the other stone, in the order of their birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Engrave the two stones with the names of the sons of Israel, in the same way that a gem cutter engraves a seal. Mount them in settings of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the two stones on the shoulder straps of the vest to be memorial stones for the people of Israel. Aaron shall bear their names on his two shoulders as a memorial before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make settings of gold
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and two chains of pure gold. Make them like braided cords, and attach the braided chains to the settings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a chest pouch to be used for making decisions, the work of a skillful craftsman. You shall make it with the same workmanship as the vest. Make it from gold and from blue, purple, and scarlet material and from fine woven linen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be square when it is folded, nine inches by nine inches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall arrange settings for precious stones on it, four rows of stones: The first row is to be carnelian, diamond, and jacinth;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the second row agate, sapphire, and emerald;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the third row beryl, jasper, and ruby;
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the fourth row topaz, onyx, and turquoise. They are to be mounted in gold settings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There are to be twelve stones corresponding to the names of the sons of Israel. Each one shall be like an engraved seal, each with the name of one of the twelve tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make braided chains of pure gold as cords for the pouch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two gold rings for the pouch, and attach the two rings to the top corners of the pouch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the two braided chains of gold into the two rings at the top corners of the pouch.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Attach the other ends of the two braided chains to the two settings, and then attach them to the shoulder straps on the front of the vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two rings of gold, and put them on the two lower corners of the pouch, on its inside edge, which is toward the vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two more gold rings, and attach them to the two shoulder straps of the vest in the front, close to the bottom where it is joined to the band of the vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tie the rings on the pouch to the rings on the vest with a blue cord, so that the pouch is right next to the band of the vest, so that the pouch does not swing out from the vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever he goes into the Holy Place, Aaron shall wear the pouch for making decisions, which bears the names of the sons of Israel, over his heart as a constant memorial before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall put the Urim and the Thummim into the pouch for making decisions, and they shall be over Aaron’s heart whenever he goes before the Lord. Aaron shall bear the means of making decisions for the people of Israel on his heart before the Lord continually.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make the robe that is to be worn under the vest. It is to be all blue.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to have an opening in the middle of the top of it for the head. It is to have a woven binding around the opening, like the opening of a collar, to prevent it from tearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To be placed around its hem you shall make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet material. Alternate them with gold bells
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (a gold bell, then a pomegranate, a gold bell, then a pomegranate), all around the hem of the robe.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The robe shall be on Aaron when he ministers, and its sound will be heard when he goes into the Holy Place before the Lord and when he comes out, so that he will not die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make a medallion of pure gold and engrave on it (like the engravings on a seal): Holy to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall attach it to a blue cord to fasten it to the turban. It is to be placed on the front of the turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall be on Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron will bear any guilt in regard to the holy things, which the people of Israel consecrate as their holy gifts. The medallion shall always be on his forehead, so that the offerings may be accepted in the presence of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall weave the tunic of fine linen, and you shall make a turban of fine linen, and you shall make a sash, the work of an embroiderer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make tunics for Aaron’s sons, and you shall make sashes for them, and you shall make small pointed turbans for them, to give them honor and splendor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put them on your brother Aaron and on his sons along with him, anoint them, and ordain them for their work and consecrate them, so that they may minister to me in the priest’s office.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make linen pants for them to cover their naked flesh. The pants shall reach from the waist to the thighs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are to be worn by Aaron and his sons whenever they go into the Tent of Meeting, or whenever they come near the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so that they do not incur guilt and die. This shall be a permanent regulation for him and for his descendants after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what you shall do to them to set them apart as holy, so that they can minister to me in the priest’s office:
Take one young bull and two rams without defect,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: unleavened bread, unleavened rolls mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers anointed with oil. Make them from fine wheat flour.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put them into one basket and bring them in the basket when you bring the bull and the two rams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring Aaron and his sons to the entrance of the Tent of Meeting and wash them with water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the garments and put them on Aaron: the tunic, the robe to be worn under the vest, the vest, and the pouch. Clothe him with the sash of the vest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Set the turban on his head and put the holy crest on the turban.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take the anointing oil and pour it on his head to anoint him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall bring his sons and put tunics on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Clothe them with sashes—Aaron and his sons—and bind small pointed turbans on them. Then they shall possess the priesthood by means of a perpetual regulation. You shall ordain Aaron and his sons for their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bring the bull in front of the Tent of Meeting. Then Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the bull.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter the bull in the presence of the Lord at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take some of the bull’s blood and put it on the horns of the altar with your finger, and pour out all the rest of the blood at the base of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take all the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys with the fat that is on them, and burn them on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the meat of the bull, its hide, and its intestines and their contents, you shall burn with fire outside of the camp. This is a sin offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take the first ram. Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the ram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter the ram, and take its blood and splash it all around on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall cut the ram into pieces, wash its internal organs and its legs, and put them with the other pieces and with its head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall burn the whole ram on the altar. This is a whole burnt offering to the Lord. It is a pleasant aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then take the other ram. Aaron and his sons shall lay their hands on the head of the ram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you shall slaughter the ram. Take some of its blood and put it on the tip of Aaron’s right ear, on the tip of the right ear of his sons, on the thumb of their right hand, and on the big toe of their right foot, and splash the blood all around on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take some of the blood that is on the altar and some of the anointing oil and spatter it on Aaron and on his garments and on his sons and on the garments of his sons, who are with him. So he and his garments and his sons and his sons’ garments shall be consecrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From this ram take the fat, the fat tail, the fat that covers the internal organs, the lobe of the liver, the two kidneys with the fat that is on them, and the right thigh (for this is a ram for the dedication),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and one loaf of bread, one roll made with oil, and one wafer out of the basket of unleavened bread that is before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall put all of this in Aaron’s hands and in his sons’ hands, and you shall wave them as a wave offering before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you shall take them from their hands and burn them on the altar for the burnt offering as a pleasant aroma before the Lord. This is an offering made by fire to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the breast from Aaron’s ram of ordination and wave it as a wave offering before the Lord, and it shall be your portion of the sacrifice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Consecrate the breast of the wave offering and the thigh of the elevated offering, which are waved and lifted up, from the ram of ordination. They are for Aaron and for his sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall belong to Aaron and his sons perpetually as their portion of the offering from the people of Israel, because it is an elevated offering. It shall be an elevated offering from the people of Israel from their sacrifices, from their fellowship offerings, that is, their elevated offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The holy garments of Aaron shall belong to his descendants after him, so they are to wear them while they are being anointed and ordained for their work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The son who is to be high priest in Aaron’s place shall put them on for seven days when he comes into the Tent of Meeting to minister in the Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take the ram of ordination and boil its meat in a holy place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron and his sons shall eat the meat of the ram and the bread that is in the basket at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall eat those things with which atonement was made at their ordination and consecration, but a non-priest shall not eat them, because they are holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If any of the meat or the bread from the ordination remains until the next morning, you shall burn the remainder with fire. It must not be eaten, because it is holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you shall do to Aaron and to his sons, exactly as I have commanded you. You shall ordain them for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Every day you shall offer a bull as a sin offering for atonement, and you shall purify the altar when you make atonement for it, and you shall anoint it to make it holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For seven days you shall make atonement for the altar to make it holy. The altar shall be most holy. Whatever touches the altar shall become holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now this is what you shall offer on the altar regularly, every day: two lambs a year old.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The first lamb you shall offer in the morning, and the other lamb you shall offer at twilight.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the first lamb offer two quarts of fine flour mixed with a quart of beaten olive oil, and a quart of wine for a drink offering.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other lamb you shall offer at twilight, and you shall offer with it the same grain offering and the same drink offering as in the morning, for a pleasant aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It shall be presented as a regular burnt offering throughout your generations at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting before the Lord. There I will meet with you to speak to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There I will meet with the people of Israel, and the place will be made holy by my glory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will consecrate the Tent of Meeting and the altar. I will also consecrate Aaron and his sons to minister to me in the priest’s office.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will dwell among the people of Israel and I will be their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will know that I am the Lord their God, who brought them out of the land of Egypt, so that I may dwell among them. I am the Lord their God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall make an altar on which to burn incense. Make it of acacia wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is to be eighteen inches long and eighteen inches wide. It is to be square, and three feet high. Its horns are to be one piece with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Overlay it with pure gold—its top, all its sides, and its horns. Make a gold border around it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make two gold rings to place under its border. Make them for each of its two opposite sides. They will serve as holders for poles with which to carry it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make the poles of acacia wood, and overlay them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Put the altar in front of the veil that hides the Ark of the Testimony, in front of the atonement seat that is above the Testimony, where I will meet with you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron shall burn incense made of fragrant spices on it every morning. When he tends the lamps, he shall burn the incense.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Aaron lights the lamps at twilight, he shall burn it as the regular incense before the Lord throughout your generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall offer no other incense on it, no burnt offering, and no grain offering, and you shall pour no drink offering on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron shall make atonement on its horns once a year. With the blood of the sin offering for atonement, once a year he shall make atonement for it throughout your generations. It is most holy to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “When you count the men of Israel to register them, each man shall give to the Lord a redemption price for his life as you register him, so that there is no plague among them as you register them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each one shall give this redemption as he passes over to the group which has already been registered—half a shekel according to the shekel of the sanctuary (the shekel is twenty gerahs), half a shekel for an offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everyone who passes over to the group that has already been registered, those twenty years old and older, shall give the special elevated offering to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The rich shall not give more, and the poor shall not give less than the half shekel when you give the elevated offering for the Lord to redeem your lives.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall take the redemption money from the people of Israel, and you shall designate it for the work of the Tent of Meeting so that it may be a memorial for the people of Israel before the Lord, to redeem your lives.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “You shall also make a large bronze basin in which to wash. Its pedestal shall also be bronze. Put it between the Tent of Meeting and the altar, and put water in it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron and his sons shall wash their hands and their feet with water from it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they go into the Tent of Meeting, they must wash with water so that they will not die. They shall wash whenever they come near the altar to minister, to burn an offering made by fire to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They shall wash their hands and their feet so that they do not die. This shall be a permanent regulation for them, for Aaron and for his descendants throughout their generations.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses again. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Take fine spices: twelve and a half pounds of liquid myrrh, half as much (six and a quarter pounds) of fragrant cinnamon, six and a quarter pounds of fragrant cane,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: twelve and a half pounds of cassia (weighed by the shekel of the sanctuary), and one gallon of olive oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Make it into a holy anointing oil, a perfume mixed with the skill of a perfume maker. It will be a holy anointing oil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Use it to anoint the Tent of Meeting, the Ark of the Testimony,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the table and all its utensils, the lampstand and its utensils, the altar for incense,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the altar for burnt offering with all its utensils, and the basin with its pedestal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall consecrate them so that they may be most holy. Whatever touches them will be holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You shall anoint Aaron and his sons and set them apart, so that they may minister to me in the priest’s office.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Speak to the people of Israel. Tell them, ‘This shall be a holy anointing oil for me throughout your generations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do not pour it on the flesh of anyone who is not a priest. Do not make any other perfume like it with the same ingredients. It is holy. It shall be holy to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever mixes any perfume like it or whoever puts any of it on anyone who is not a priest shall be cut off from his people.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord said to Moses, “Take fragrant spices, gum resin, shechelet, and helbanum, fragrant spices with pure frankincense. Use an equal weight of each ingredient,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and make incense from it, a blend made with the skill of a perfume maker, seasoned with salt, pure and holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Grind some of it very fine, and put some of it in front of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting where I will make myself known to you. It shall be most holy to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you make incense for yourselves, you shall not make any with this recipe. You shall regard it as holy to the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever makes any fragrance like that for himself shall be cut off from his people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Look, here is Bezalel, the son of Uri, the son of Hur, from the tribe of Judah. I have called him by name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have filled him with the Spirit of God, with wisdom, understanding, and knowledge, and with skill in all kinds of crafts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has the ability to create designs. He works with gold, silver, and bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He is able to cut and engrave precious stones and mount them. He can also carve wood. He works skillfully in all kinds of crafts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Not only that, but I have also appointed Oholiab son of Ahisamak, from the tribe of Dan, to work with him. I have put wisdom into the heart of all the skilled craftsmen, so that they may make everything that I have commanded you:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Tent of Meeting, the Ark of the Testimony, the atonement seat that is on it, all the furnishings for the tent,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the table and its vessels and accessories, the pure gold lampstand with all its utensils, the altar for incense,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the altar for burnt offerings with all its utensils, the basin and its pedestal,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the finely woven garments (the holy garments for Aaron the priest), the garments for his sons to minister in the priest’s office,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the anointing oil, and the incense made of fragrant spices for the Holy Place. The skilled craftsmen shall do everything just as I commanded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Speak to the people of Israel. Tell them, ‘You must observe my Sabbaths diligently, because the Sabbath is a sign between me and you throughout your generations, so that you may know that I am the Lord, who sets you apart as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So you shall observe the Sabbath, for it is holy to you. Everyone who profanes it must certainly be put to death, for if anyone does any work on the Sabbath, his life shall be cut off from among his people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On six days work may be done, but the seventh day is a sabbath of complete rest, holy to the Lord. Whoever does any work on the Sabbath day must certainly be put to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore the people of Israel shall observe the Sabbath by keeping the Sabbath throughout their generations as a perpetual covenant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It is a permanent sign between me and the people of Israel, for in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, and on the seventh day he rested and was refreshed.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Lord had finished speaking with Moses on Mount Sinai, he gave him the two tablets of the Testimony, stone tablets, written with God’s finger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the people saw that it took so long for Moses to come down from the mountain, the people gathered around Aaron and said to him, “Get up, make a god for us, who will go before us, because this Moses, the man who brought us up out of the land of Egypt—we do not know what has become of him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aaron said to them, “Pull off the gold earrings from your wives and sons and daughters and bring them to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people pulled off their gold earrings and brought them to Aaron.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took what they handed him and shaped it with an engraving tool and made it into a bull calf cast out of metal. Then they said, “This is your god, Israel, which brought you up out of the land of Egypt.”
verses.speaker: Narrator
